p: The timing of the effects also needs to be considered. Some of the impacts may be immediate, that is, during the crisis (e.g. financial implications, availability restrictions), and some may be in the longer term, that is, later consequences in the months or years after the crisis. In the most comprehensive systematic review on the topic of economic crises, de Goeij et al. 2 found evidence for both mechanisms: across many countries, the psychological distress mechanism was observed mainly in men. However, the tighter budget constraints mechanism seemed to play a role in all population subgroups across all countries. For other mechanisms examined (deterioration in the social situation, fear of losing one's job and increased non‚Äêworking time), empirical evidence was scarce or absent or had small to moderate effect sizes.
